hints.content:
The $\purpleD{\text{numerator}}$ is the number of equal parts being counted.

The $\blueD{\text{denominator}}$ is the number of equal parts in **one** whole. 

$\dfrac{\purpleD{\text{numerator}}}{\blueD{\text{denominator}}}$

The $\blueD{\text{denominator}}$ is $\blueD2$, so we need $\blueD2$ equal pieces in each whole.

The $\purpleD{\text{numerator}}$ is $\purpleD{3}$, so we need $\purpleD3$ equal parts shaded.

The following images show $\dfrac32$ shaded:


[[☃ image 1]]


[[☃ image 2]]

options.alt: Two circles. Each circle is divided into 2 equal parts. The first circle has 1 part shaded. The second circle has 2 parts shaded. !
Three circles. Each circle is divided into 2 equal parts. All circles have 1 part shaded. !

question.content:
Each circle is equal to one whole.

**Which images show $\dfrac3{2}$ shaded?**

[[☃ radio 2]]

choices.content: ![Two circles. Each circle is divided into 3 equal parts. Both circles have 2 parts shaded.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/f8d94ca174bb94c55bed8b302e87023f66689fa8)

![Two circles. Each circle is divided into 2 equal parts. The first circle has 1 part shaded. The second circle has 2 parts shaded.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/9332e8655392dbf0e4b0c0289b3720a3fea602bc)
![Three circles. Each circle is divided into 2 equal parts. All circles have 1 part shaded. ](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/c90071d254104b71a11139017c456d93c060c6dd)
![Two circles. Each circle is divided into 3 equal parts. Both circles have 2 parts shaded.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/7df2d7b54a8ab1b7cd94d06adc4dfe1ce297feb6)
